While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Diên Lộc nhóm 01 (1).

Dung is married with four grown children. Dung owns and operates a business selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 3.000.000 VND a month.

In 2010, Dung joined SEDA to gain access to financial services.  Dung has repaid loans previously taken out of 5,152,000 VND.  This loan was used to purchase ingredients such as wheat, rice, beef for breakfast sales.  She is now requesting a loan of 7,392,000 VND to buy feed for the chickens, to buy bowls, chopsticks purchased for the business process.  Monday will be taken out loans.  Plans to use additional income from business to improve overall living conditions of families.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Ly is a 39-year-old female who is requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support her cattle livestock business.


2.  Bắc is a 39-year-old female who is requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support business and to buy feed for pigs.


3.  Thành is a 24-year-old female who is requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business such as tables, chairs, beds. .


4.  Hoa is a 39-year-old female who is requesting a 6.944.000 VND loan to buy food for her pig business.


5.  May is a 24-year-old male who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to buy food for his pigs and chickens.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Dung là 57 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Dung là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Diên Lộc nhóm 01 (1).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán thức ăn nhanh & những loại thực phẩm cao cấp khác trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Dung thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 2 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Dung kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2010, Dung đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy.  Dung đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các thành phần thô cần thiết để chế tạo sản phẩm để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.392.000 VND để mua thức ăn cho gà và mua bát đũa kinh doanh hàng ăn sáng.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Ly là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.944.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi bò.


2.  Bắc  là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.944.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh  để hỗ trợ kinh doanh và mua thức ăn cho lợn .


3.  Thành là 24 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.944.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất như bàn, ghế,giường.


4.  Hoa  là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.944.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi mua thức ăn cho lợn.


5.  May là 24 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi và mua thức ăn cho lợn, gà.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to buy feed for the chickens, to buy bowls, chopsticks

loans.name: Kilia

texts.en:
Kilia is 30 years of age and married with five children. She owns and operates a business venture, planting and harvesting taro for sale.  She has one year of experience in this business.

Kilia needs a loan of 1,500 WST to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxone.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or $208 per week) to improve the business.

In 2009, Kilia joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Kilia's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.

loans.name: Federico

texts.en:
Federico works as a farmer in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del sur. He has been growing rice for 30 years. He earns 5,000 PHP per month doing this farming. 

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He hopes to earn better and to be able to supply all their basic needs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Maimoaga

texts.en:
Maimoaga is 29 years of age and married with one child. She owns and operates a business venture, baking and selling a variety of baked goods in the local community.  She has many years of experience in this business.   

Maimoaga needs a loan of 1,500 WST to purchase baking equipment.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or $208 per week) to improve the business.

In 2010, Maimoaga joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Maimoaga's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase baking equipment.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 43 years old and is a married woman with 3 children. The oldest child is 25 years old. 

Josephine is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del sur. She has been growing rice for 10 years. She also owns and manages a sari-sari store. She sells various items like soap and shampoo. Josephine earns 15,000 PHP per month from her businesses.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. In the future, she hopes to lift her family from the difficulties of life.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 20 years of age and she is a single woman with one child. Helen owns and operates a business venture, selling lavalavas (bottom-half wrap-around prints worn by both men and women).  She has three years of experience in this business. 

Helen needs a loan of 1,500 WST to purchase additional fabrics and materials.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or $208 per week) to improve the business.

In 2010, Helen joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Helen's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and materials.

loans.name: Lagaali

texts.en:
Lagaali is 65 years of age and married with four children. She owns and operates a business venture, selling baked goods in the local community.  She has many years of experience in this business. 

Lagaali needs a loan of 1,500 WST to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or $208 per week) to improve the business.

In 2010, Lagaali joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Lagaali's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Leonilo

texts.en:
Leonilo is from the village of Sagrada Familia, Tambulig Zamnboanga del sur. He is 43 years old. Leonilo is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Leonilo owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Leonilo has been engaged in his business for over 21 years and earns approximately 12745 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Leonilo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonilo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used  to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Leonilo is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. It will also help him to finance for farm maintenance. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Leonilo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and to finance for farm maintenance

location.town: Sagrada Familia, Tambulig, Zamboanga del sur

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is a married woman with 2 children. Her oldest child is only 5 years old. 

Maricel is farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del sur. She has been growing rice for 5 years. She earns 5,000 PHP per month doing this farming.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. In the future, she hopes to improve her business and be able to sustain her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie is a married woman with 4 children. She is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan del sur. She has been growing rice for 8 years. She earns 15,000 PHP per month doing farming.

This loan will be used to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and seeds. In the future, she hopes to improve her farm and her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Sonya

texts.en:
Sonya is a 28-year-old lady. She is married to Bernard, a 37-year-old man who is currently working in a private company. Sonya and Bernard are blessed with a son, Kiand, who is one year old. 

Sonya and her family are living with her mother-in-law and a sister-in-law in a modest house. Sonya operates a computer rental business in order to support her husband in meeting their family needs. Actually this business has been running for 4 years, since Bernard was still single. Now, Bernard is working in another company, so Sonya took over the business.

Sonya is grateful as the income generated from the business can be added to her husband’s income. Her business income depends on how many costumers she has and how many hours the customers spend on the computer. Currently Sonya has 3 computers to be rented but it is not enough to meet the customers’ needs. Sonya wants to add one more computer for her business so she will be able to generate more income and better meet her family's needs. 

Sonya would like to request a loan of IDR 4,500,000 from TLM. She wants to purchase one computer for her business. Sonya hopes that her loan application will be approved by TLM so she can improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase one computer.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Mrs. Sem is 41 years old and a resident in Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province, where she raises chickens for meat and eggs. She is married with two single children, one of whom is a student who studies in public school, while the other works as a seamstress. Her husband’s name is Mr. Yang who works with her in the business. Mrs. Sem has applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase additional feed and materials to repair the chicken cage.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and materials for repair her chicken cage.

loans.name: Loeurng

texts.en: Mrs. Loeurng is a local farmer who has spent most of her life cultivating rice on her fertile land. From her crop planting business, she earns around US$2.5 each day to cover expenses such as utilities, food  and education. To generate extra income, her husband works as a garment factory worker and he gets a monthly salary. As the rainy season is coming, Mrs. Loeurng would like a loan to buy some farm inputs needed for her farm.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cement, pebbles and other materials to make hollow blocks

loans.name: Daim

texts.en: Mr. Daim has been living in Siem Reap Province. To earn a living, he works as a motor-taxi driver and earns an income of approximately $5 per day. To meet the family’s living expenses, his wife works as a waitress in a hotel for a fixed salary. They have one child who is very young and still lives under their care. He runs his business very well because he has skills in communication which he uses with his customers. However, his income is low as his motorcycle is too small to carry many passengers. Mr. Daim has decided to ask for a loan of $1100 to buy a new motorcycle (Tuk Tuk) so that he can increase the number of passengers he can transport.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she operates a food stall business that contributes to her other source of living. She faces the major challenge of competition from other vegetable stall operators in the area. 

With the KSHS 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of vegetables, cooking oil, beans and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of vegetables, cooking oil, beans and wheat flour.

loans.name: Mwanamvita

texts.en:
Mwanamvita is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby.  She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of beans, rice and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of beans, rice and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is competition from other food stall operators.  She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of beans, rice, cooking oil and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of beans, rice, cooking oil and wheat flour.

loans.name: Jaime

texts.en: Jaime is a 40-year-old married man with four children. His oldest child is 10 years old. Jaime is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. He primarily grows rice to sell. Jaime works hard to provide the needs of his family. He asked for a loan to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He hopes to expand his farm in the future.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past six years, she has operated a business selling Khangas from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is competition from other Khanga selling businesses in the area. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the KSHS 15,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of Khangas for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of Khangas for resale.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is 31 years old and married. She has two children aged seven and six. Joan and her husband are both farmers. They work together to keep their farm productive. Rice is the primary crop that they grow. Joan does her best to help provide for her family's needs. She also makes sure her kids eat well and are healthy.

Joan's loan will be used to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy three cows

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean is 43 years old and married to a farmer. She has two children aged 16 and 15.

Mary Jean started her farming business four years ago. She helps her husband till their land located in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She grows rice crops and keeps the farm free of weeds and pests. She earns about 5,300 PHP per month from farming. Mary Jean also raises pigs in her backyard. She sells the pigs at the market.

Mary Jean's loan will be used to buy fertilizers, seeds and pig feed. She hopes to prosper in life.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds and pig feed

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a married woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Halima has operated a poultry business for the past five years, selling to hotel operators and neighbors. She faces the major challenge of disease outbreak in her business.  She dreams of expanding her poultry business in the future.

With the KSHS 15,000 loan, she wants to purchase chicks and poultry feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase chicks and poultry feed.

loans.name: Mehpara

texts.en: Mehpara is a 30-year-old woman from Bilasuvar. Her children are attending primary and secondary schools. Her husband is a farmer and Mehpara actively helps him. They do animal husbandry and breed cattle. They have been in this business for the last eight years. The income from this business is the only source of profit for the family. Mehpara and her husband plan to expand their business. For this reason, she requested from Aqroinvest and Kiva a loan of 600 AZN. This is the first loan for Mehpara and after repaying this loan, she plans to apply for more loans.

loans.use: to buy one cow

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina is 38 years old and married. She has two children aged 14 and 10. Both of her children go to school. 

Medina is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She primarily grows rice crops to sell. She earns about 3,000 PHP per month from farming. Medina wants to improve her earnings and she works hard. She requested a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers. She also plans to use part of the loan to pay for the educational expenses of her children. Medina hopes for her business to prosper.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers and pay for educational expenses

loans.name: Dorinda

texts.en:
Dorinda is from the village of Lopoc, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 66 years old. Dorinda is married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Dorinda owns & operates a business harvesting & selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Dorinda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Dorinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dorinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell. Dorinda is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Dorinda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo is 23 years of age and married with an infant child. He earns about 25,000 Philippines pesos per month as a farmer working in the Philippines. He grows rice and has been doing it for five years. 

Eduardo is asking for a loan to purchase fertilizers and seeds of rice to be planted for his large crop. He dreams that his business will be profitable someday to uplift their living conditions and continuously bestow his family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds to be planted in his farm.

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia, 34, is a married woman with two kids. The oldest is 7 years old, while the youngest is only 2. Nemia is engaged in farming. She grows rice crops to sell. Nemia works hard to help provide for the needs in her household. She also wants to be able to support her oldest child's education.

Nemia requested a loan and plans to use it to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for her business to prosper.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Mrs. Phon, aged 32, is a village woman living in Prey Chor district of Phnom Penh City. She sells a variety of merchandise and has been running this business since 2000. She earns around $1.75 each day to cover her family's expenses. Her husband is a domestic farmer who has been earning money by cultivating rice for many years ago. Mrs. Phon has four single children; most of them are students at the local school. Mrs. Phon would like to request a loan to buy some fertilizers for their crop growing. With the rest of the funds, she will purchase a piece of farmland from her neighbor to increase the size of their crops. This loan will provide her entire family with an additional fixed asset.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and to purchase a piece of farmland.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia is 62 years old and is a married woman with four kids. She is engaged in farming. She has been growing rice for 30 years. Ofelia earns about 5,000 PHP per month from her farming.

Ofelia's loan will be used to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to earn more and have her own capital in the near future.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Lorife

texts.en:
Mrs. Lorife, 25 years of age and married, is a resident of Garang, Tangub City, Mis. Occ. She is married to a single motor driver. They were blessed with two children, who both are old enough to attend school. That has created a financial strain for their family. 

She joined PAGLAUM MPC two years ago because she is very much interested in our products and services. PMPC is one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao and was awarded Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006.

Since she is receiving her third loan, she is requesting PHP7,000 to purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business. The future income from this loan will be used for daily basic needs, savings and loan repayments.

loans.use: to purchase more raw ingredients for her snack vending business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts for sale

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is from the village of Goaw, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 41 years old. Marilyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for more than eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 9,800 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marilyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Shadia

texts.en:
With the help of her husband who is a driver for Jordan University, Shadia, 29 years old and a mother, opened a small grocery store at her house, that could serve the surrounding people in the neighborhood.

Since the beginning of her small business three years ago, she was able to add more types of goods such as cleaning products to what she is selling, but still she needs to get more goods based on what her customers are asking for, and that’s why she is applying for this loan.

In the future, Shadia wants to open a supermarket in an active area to have a continuous source of income for the family.

loans.use: To include more goods in the grocery store.

loans.name: Firat

texts.en:
Firat is a single, 25 year-old man.  He has an elementary school education. He lives with his parents and sister and he breeds cattle for a living.  Firat has been in this business for six years. He gets up very early every day to milk the cows and sells dairy in the Bilasuvar bazaar. 

Last year, he had a good economic income. Now Firat wants to get married and that is why he needs to expand his business.  He is going to use his 1100 AZN loan to purchase three cows.  In the future, Firat hopes to buy a bigger farm to support his growing family.

loans.use: to buy three cows

loans.name: Johnny

texts.en:
Johnny is 42 years old and is married with 2 children. He is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. He has been growing rice for 25 years. Johnny earns about 5000 PHP per month from farming. Aside from rice farming, Johnny also raises pigs in his backyard. The family also has a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages.

Johnny's loan will be used to buy fertilizer, piglets and feed. He hopes for his businesses to prosper and for his family's living situation to improve.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, piglets and feed

loans.name: Mwari

texts.en:
Mwari is a married woman with 5 children, 4 of whom attend school. She owns a house that has  neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 4 years, Mwari has operated a charcoal-selling business. She sells at retail and from home to her neighbors. In addition, she also operates a dumpling-selling business which contributes another source of income. She faces a major challenge of competition from other charcoal sellers in the market. She dreams of expanding and increasing her sales volume in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of charcoal, as well as wheat flour and sugar for making dumplings. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of charcoal to resell, wheat flour and sugar.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is a married woman with 3 children. Her husband works as a farmer and a welder.

Rosita is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She and her husband till their land together. They primarily grow rice to sell. When free of farming duties, Rosita's husband works as a welder. Rosita also raises pigs in their backyard.

This loan will be used to buy fertilizers, feed and materials for welding. She hopes for her ventures to prosper.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, feed and materials for welding

loans.name: Euphrasie

texts.en:
Euphrasie is a 53-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur who sells foodstuffs.  She has been running her business for 14 years and has used the profits generated from it to provide education and food for her children.

Euphrasie is widowed and has 4 children between the ages of 22 and 31.  The eldest is married and the others are still in school.

She will use this loan to purchase green bananas, Irish potatoes, and beans that she will sell at her business.  She will use the profits from her business to accumulate savings that she will use to feed her children and provide capital for her eldest.

She runs her business with the ambition of one day becoming a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy green bananas, Irish potatoes and beans to resell

loans.name: San's Group

texts.en:
San is a 38 year-old male living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  San is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Diên Lộc nhóm 03 (3).

San is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, San owns and operates a business raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale.  San has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 2.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

San joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  He is now requesting a loan of 5.152.000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed for his pigs and other supplies.  The loan will be the 1st loan taken out by San from SEDA.  San plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the his business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Trang is a 34 year-old male who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support his business in the agriculture sector raising livestock by buying chicken feed  .

2.  Học  is a 30 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising chickens.

3.  Tiền  is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising cattle .

4.  S. is a 46 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising chickens and pigs.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Mrs. Elena is 32 years of age, married, and a resident of Silangit, Tangub City.
With this condition, they had financial hardships in meeting their daily basic needs. She decided to engage in snack vending and she has now been in this business for 3 years. She earns an average net income of P3,500.00 a month which greatly benefits the family. 

Mrs. Elena joined PAGLAUM MPC 3 years ago because she was interested in the organization's products and services.  PAGLAUM has been recognized as one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao and was named the Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines at the  COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006. 

This is Mrs. Elena's sixth loan.  She has been given a loan amount of P14,900.00 to purchased raw ingredients for her snack vending. The future income from this business will be used for daily basic needs and savings and loan repayments. She is hoping that this business will become more successful and more progressive.

loans.use: to purchased raw ingredients for her snack vending business

location.town: Silangit, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindana

loans.name: Terry

texts.en:
Terry is a married woman with 2 children, one of whom attends school while the other one is still too young. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 5 years, she has operated a clothes-selling business.  She sells in a shop to her neighbors, both men and women. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and insecurity in her business. Terry dreams of become a wholesale supplier of clothes in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of clothes at wholesale and resell at a retail price. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes at wholesale and resell at a retail price.

loans.name: Bintiathuman

texts.en:
Bintiathuman is a widow with six children, 2 of whom still attend school. She owns a house that has no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a fish-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors. Her major challenge is competition from other fish operators.  She dreams of establishing a fish-selling shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of fish and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fish and cooking oil.

loans.name: Azad

texts.en:
Azad is a 30-year-old married man. He is blessed with two daughters, who go to a local secondary school. Azad and his family live in a small settlement built for refugee families, in Bilasuvar district. He fled to Bilasuvar from Nagorno-Karabakh in the beginning of the 1990s.

The family's budget depends mainly on the income from the cattle-breeding business that Azad started in 2003. Nowadays he earns about 350 AZN a month through selling dairy and meat products in the local bazaar. With the help of this first loan in the amount of 1200 AZN, Azad purchased three cows. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase three cows

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is a mother of 8 children between the ages of 1 to 16 years.  She sells cassava and she has done this for the past 2 years.  This business has enabled her to pay school fees for her children and to meet the needs of her family.

Hawa is very hard-working.  She is requesting a loan to buy more cassava for sale.  She plans to save all her profits and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy cassava for sale.

loans.name: Subira

texts.en:
Subira is a married man with five children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Subira has operated an electronics shop, selling to his neighbors and passersby. He faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in his business. He dreams of establishing another business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, he wants to purchase electronics equipment for his shop. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase electronics equipment for his shop.

loans.name: Marselina

texts.en:
Marselina is a 32-year-old lady and a mother of three children: Riniyati, 12 years old; Reinaldy, and Fresilia, 1 year old. Both Riniyati and Reinaldy are still at elementary school.

Marselina operates a pig breeding business as the income source for her family. She has been involved in this business for five months. Marselina was interested in operating this business because of the high demand for pork in the market as well as the fair market price for pork. Marselina thought that she had to take this opportunity to improve her family's lives. 

Marselina initiated the business by purchasing three piglets, aged 1 month, to be raised. She is expecting that from the business she will be able to generate more income for her family.
 
Actually, Marselina has sold one pig, but the income that she earned was not as much as her expectation since the pig could not achieve proper weight. Marselina realized that she is not able to feed the piglets with good fodder because she has only limited capital. 

Marselina plans to enhance her business by purchasing a piglet and fodder. She has been involved in TLM’s group lending program for two cycles and now she is moving to the Individual Lending Program and requesting a loan of IDR 4,500,000. The loan would be spent on one piglet and a few sacks of fodder. Marselina is hoping that TLM is willing to approve her loan application so she will be able to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase one piglet and a few sacks of fodder.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn, 40, is a resident of Silangit, Tangub City. She is married to Noel, a carpenter. 

In order to help her husband in terms of finances, she decided to engage in business. She has operated a sari-sari (variety) store for 10 years. At this time, she is earning an average net income of not less than PHP 5,500 a month, which is very helpful in meeting the basic daily needs of the family. 

Aside from the sari-sari store, she is also a barangay (village) councilor, receiving PHP 3,200 per month as her honorarium. 

She joined Paglaum MPC one year ago because she is very much interested and well-served with our products and services.

With good credit performance from her first loan, she was given a privilege to seek an amount of PHP 7,000 as her second loan to purchase more products for her sari-sari store. The income from this loan will be used for loan repayments and savings for their children for future use, especially in education.

loans.use: to purchase more products for her sari-sari store.

location.town: Silangit, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindana

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past 10 years, she has operated a food stall business, selling at the market and from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she also sells cashew nuts, which contributes to her income. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Asha dreams of expanding her business in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn, 52 years of age, is a resident of Garang, Tangub City. She is married to Danilo, a carpenter. 

In order to help her husband in terms of finances, she decided to engage in business. She has operated a sari-sari store for 10 years. At this time, she is earning an average net income of not less than PHP 5,500 a month, which is very helpful in meeting the basic daily needs of the family. 

Aside from the sari-sari store, she is also selling various kinds of bananas. 

She joined Paglaum MPC three years ago because she is very much interested and well-served with our products and services. 

With good credit performance from her previous loans, she was given the privilege to ask for PHP 10,000 as her 15th loan, to purchase more products to sell in her retail store business. 

The income from this loan will be used for loan repayments and savings for their children's future, especially in education.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell in her retail store.

loans.name: Zacquia

texts.en:
Zacquia is 23 years old. She has one child who is two years old. She stays with her husband and they run a business together.

Zacquia owns a bakery in which she makes bread and snacks such as donuts. She has done this business for four years and this business has enabled her to feed her family.

She is requesting a loan to buy wheat flour and cooking oil for baking so that she can increase the quantity of the products she sells and hence make more profits.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is from the village of Lumbayao, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 33 years old. Merlita is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Merlita sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Merlita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Merlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Merlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Merlita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Merlita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of Khanga clothes for sale.

loans.name: Anges

texts.en:
Anges is 54 years old. She has six children, ages 17 to 31 years old. They are all in school apart from the eldest.

Anges is a widow and she has overcome many challenges while raising her children. 

She sells different kinds of bags, most especially women's bags, and she has done this business for many years. This business has enabled her feed her family and meet all her children's needs.

Anges is requesting a loan to buy more bags and hence make more profits.

loans.use: to buy bags for resale.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has sold household goods like maize flour and sugar. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood. With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and beans.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and beans.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a Khanga selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. (Khanga or Kikoi is traditional African cloth, wrapped around the body as clothing.) She faces a major challenge of competition from other Khanga sellers in the area. She dreams of increasing her sales volume in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of Kikoi for sale.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of Kikoi’s for sale.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a single mother of one child who attends school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 2 years, Asha has operated a Khangas business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other Khangas sellers in the area. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the 15,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase bundles of Khangas for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of Khangas for sale

loans.name: Indatwa Group

texts.fr: Adèle  est client d’ACB depuis 2011, elle est membre du groupe Indatwa, elle est née au Rwanda, son éducation est de 6 ans de l’école primaire, elle est mariée, elle a 37 ans, elle a 8 enfants entre 16 et 2 ans, 2 de ses enfants vont à l’école. C’est son premier cycle de prêt, Adèle va utiliser le prêt pour l’agriculture en payant main d’œuvre et les aliments pour son restaurant. Sa stratégie est l’attraction de la clientèle. Dans l’avenir, Adèle veut avoir un restaurant de première qualité dans son quartier et éduquer ses enfants  jusqu'à l’université. Elle aussi agriculteur de tomates et de riz.
texts.en: Adèle is a client of ACB since 2011. She is a member  of the Indatwa group. She is born in Rwanda. She has finished six grades of primary school. She is 37 years old. She is married, with eight children between 2 and 16 years of age, two of whom are in school. This is her first loan circle. Adèle will use her loan to pay the cost of manual labor and food items for her restaurant. Her strategy is attracting more customers. In the future, she would like to have a quality restaurant in her neighborhood and support her children’s studies through the university level. She also grows tomatoes and rice.

loans.use: to buy potatoes, rice and vegetable oil for her restaurant

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu is a married woman with 3 children, 2 of whom attend school while one is too young for school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 4 years, Tatu has operated a retail business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a clothing stall in the future.

With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, beans, sugar and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, beans, sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.fr: Emmanuel est client d’ACB depuis 2009,il est marié ,il est  il a 33 ans ,il a 1 enfant de 10 mois il a une seul personne en charge ,et il est ne en Uganda mais il est Rwandais.il a niveau d’éducation de 4 ans des études secondaire .c’est son troisième  cycle de  prêt, Emmanuel va utilise le prêt pour acheter une machine de couture ,50 paires tissus d’hommes ,30 paires tissus des femmes. Sa stratégie pour la croissance  de l’affaire est augmentée la capacité du busines, ouverture des autres ateliers. Dans l’avenir il voudrait ouvert des ateliers et avoir un grand atelier de ce district, pour sa famille il voudrait acheter une parcelle et bâtir s propre maison d’habitation.il est aussi éleveur des bovins.
texts.en:
Emmanuel has been an ACB client since 2009. He is 33 years old, married, and has a 10-month child; he has only one dependent. He is born in Uganda, but is Rwandan. He went to school up to the fourth year of high school. This is his third loan, which Emmanuel will use to buy a sewing machine, 50 pieces of fabric for men's clothing and 30 pieces of fabric for women's clothing
His strategy for business growth is to increase capacity and open new workshops. In the future he would like to open workshops and have a large workshop in this district. He would like to purchase a lot for his family and to build his own house. He also raises cattle.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine and 50 pieces of fabric

loans.name: Mwanarusi

texts.en:
Mwanarusi is a married woman with 6 children, 5 of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees.

For the past 10 years, Mwanarusi has operated a kerosene sales business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other kerosene sellers in the area. She dreams of increasing her supply of kerosene to cover a large area of customers.

With the 10,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase kerosene for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase kerosene for sale

loans.name: Aloysie

texts.en:
Aloysie is 41 years old, she has five children who are between the ages of 13-29. She sells second-hand clothes. She has been selling clothes for the past six years and her business is going well. She sells shirts, skirts, trousers, and she also sells a few foodstuffs. 

This business has enabled her pay her children's school fees. She is requesting a loan to buy more clothes and make more profits. She plans to save all her profits.

loans.use: to buy clothes

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past seven years, she has operated a food stall business, selling to children at a nearby school. Her major challenge is seasonality in the business. She dreams of establishing a restaurant in the future. 

With the loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, sugar and cooking fat for her food stall business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil

loans.name: Arcel

texts.en:
Arcel is 26 years old and is a married woman with 3 kids. The oldest is 8 years old.

Arcel is engaged in farming. She grows rice and coconuts. She makes copra to sell. Arcel has requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes for her business to prosper and for her children to have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
This is Nilda, 44, a resident of Cavite City in the Philippines. Single, she alone manages her business. She is working hard to provide income for her everyday expenses and help her siblings. 

Nilda operates a market stall store. In the Philippines, a market stall is basically a store located in the market, which sells assorted vegetable, fresh or dried fish and other raw ingredients needed for cooking. Nilda earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at retail. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1000 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy vegetables, fish and other grocery stocks to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Nilda hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams to have a stall in a big marketplace. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for vegetables, fish and other products needed in her store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more poultry to resell

loans.name: Gea

texts.en:
Gea is 30 years old and is married. She has 3 children aged 4, 6 and 8.

Gea manages a coconut farm. She makes copra to sell. She also tills a small parcel of land for growing rice. Gea applied for a loan so she could buy rice seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to earn more and save for her children's future.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
This is Marites, 49, a resident of Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Rene, an auto electrician, and mother to their only child. She, together with her husband and child, manages their household while operating the business. She works hard to provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Marites operates a market stall store. In the Philippines, a market stall is basically a store located in the market, which sells assorted vegetable, fresh and dried fish and other raw ingredients needed for cooking. Marites earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at retail. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1000 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 18,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy vegetables, fish, and other grocery stocks to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marites hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, fish, and other products needed in her store
